title: Development of a Hydrological Telemetry System in Bago River
author: Acierto, R. A. and Kawasaki, A. and Zin, W. W. and Oo, A. T. and Ra, K. and Komori, D.
quick_notes: validation/calibration but hints at usages; collaboration among stakeholders

title: Mapping Floristic Gradients of Forest Composition Using an Ordination-Regression Approach with Landsat Oli and Terrain Data in the Central Hardwoods Region
author: Adams, B. T. and Matthews, S. N. and Peters, M. P. and Prasad, A. and Iverson, L. R.
quick_notes: cool methodology for classifying forest composition, but doesn't apply it.  nmds for dim reduction, then plot to rgb for visualization?

title: Diagnosing Irrigation Performance and Water Productivity through Satellite Remote Sensing and Secondary Data in a Large Irrigation System of Pakistan
author: Ahmad, M. D. and Turral, H. and Nazeer, A.
quick_notes: uses ro data in conjunction with others to improve understanding of water consumption; this allows deeper understandings of patterns of water use equity and sustainability.  the value is in the improvement in understanding - there's no decision analyzed in the paper, but reduction in uncertainty around these values must be worth something...  do they actually quantify the improvement in uncertainty though?

title: Assessment of the Utility of Remote Sensing Techniques for Monitoring Compliance with Direct Payment Programs
author: Ahn, H. and Ryu, J. H. and Lee, K.
quick_notes: bummer, this would probably have been a good one - imrpovement in operational efficiency.  how did chatgpt summarize then?

title: Wetland Landscape Spatio-Temporal Degradation Dynamics Using the New Google Earth Engine Cloud-Based Platform: Opportunities for Non-Specialists in Remote Sensing
author: Alonso, A. and {Munoz-Carpena}, R. and Kennedy, R. E. and Murcia, C.
quick_notes: uses ndvi from modis and landsat to calculate time series of vegetation dynamics, but doesn't strictly tie to societal benefits

title: National Forest Carbon Inventories: Policy Needs and Assessment Capacity
author: Andersson, K. and Evans, T. P. and Richards, K. R.
quick_notes: focuses on forest carbon inventories to link policy and scientific communities.  ro is an important component, but not the main focus of the paper; additionally, the societal benefits (other than presumably carbon sequestration) are not a major focus

title: Mapping Landscape-Scale Peatland Degradation Using Airborne Lidar and Multispectral Data
author: Carless, D. and Luscombe, D. J. and Gatis, N. and Anderson, K. and Brazier, R. E.
quick_notes: calibration/validation clearly shows that this method has promise, but actual decisions and/or quantifications of specific societal benefits is not made.

title: The Value of Remotely Sensed vs. Field-surveyed Habitat Structure for Predicting Bird Abundance: A Case Study in Traditional Orchards
author: Chaparro, Laura and Schmieder, Klaus and Schurr, Frank M.
quick_notes: validates remote sensing as a way to predict bird abundance vs. field-survey data.  but, leaves "conservation implications" in purely conceptual terms.  ro and field survey data adds "habitat structure" info to climatic and land use variables.

title: Revisiting the Environmental Kuznets Curve for City-Level Co2 Emissions: Based on Corrected Npp-Viirs Nighttime Light Data in China
author: Chen, Hongxing and Zhang, Xiaoling and Wu, Rongwei and Cai, Tianyi
quick_notes: estimates co2 emissions from viirs night light data, and looks for a kuznets inflection point at which increasing wealth starts to lead to reduced pollution (and doesn't find that inflection point).  but: no decisions, no quantification of societal benefits.

title: The Role of Remote Sensing in the Development of Smart Indicators for Ecosystem Services Assessment
author: Dawson, T. P. and Cutler, M. E. J. and Brown, C.
quick_notes: shows that various ro data (landsat, sar, worldview2) can be useful in detecting/observing state of environmental biodiversity (forest/carbon storage, forest biomass/carbon, and peat bogs respectively), they don't actually attempt to quantify the added value.

title: Remote Sensing of Soil and Water Quality in Agroecosystems
author: De Paul Obade, V. and Lal, R. and Chen, J.
quick_notes: looks at many remote observation options and potential for gleaning information on surface water and soil characteristics, but doesn't examine decisions or effect of improved information.

title: Lake Nasser Evaporation Reduction Study
author: Ebaid, Hala M. I. and Ismail, Sherine S.
quick_notes: maybe: uses landsat for temperature data on lake, to feed into an evaporation model.  results can inform a decision to disconnect khors to reduce evaporation? but did it really depend on the landsat data?

title: Broadband, Red-Edge Information from Satellites Improves Early Stress Detection in a New Mexico Conifer Woodland
author: Eitel, J. U. H. and Vierling, L. A. and Litvak, M. E. and Long, D. S. and Schulthess, U. and Ager, A. A. and Krofcheck, D. J. and Stoscheck, L.
quick_notes: while they show that they can use ro data to detect insect-stressed trees much earlier, they don't really tie it to some quantified improvement in societal value.
notes: good example of one that shows a strong scientific value but not translating to societal value

title: Success Stories of Satellite Radar Altimeter Applications
author: Eldardiry, Hisham and Hossain, Faisal and Srinivasan, Margaret and Tsontos, Vardis
quick_notes: great examples of "success stories"

title: Combining Passive Acoustics and Environmental Data for Scaling up Ecosystem Monitoring: A Test on Coral Reef Fishes
author: Elise, Simon and Guilhaumon, Francois and {Mou-Tham}, Gerard and {Urbina-Barreto}, Isabel and Vigliola, Laurent and Kulbicki, Michel and Bruggemann, J. Henrich
quick_notes: passive acoustic, not satellite or anything? combines visual surveys with passive acoustic surveys to predict fish assemblage structures.  "globally, the acoustic data showed relatiely low added value in predicting fish assemblage structures."  does not explicitly value in terms of societal benefits though
notes: looks like a cool study - includes functional entities?

title: Big Data Technology Oriented to Wetland Resource Ecosystem Value Evaluation
author: Fan, L.
quick_notes: uses "big data" to estimate the value of ecosystem services, not the value of the data for informing decisions

title: Competition and Burn Severity Determine Post-Fire Sapling Recovery in a Nationally Protected Boreal Forest of China: An Analysis from Very High-Resolution Satellite Imagery
author: Fang, L. and Crocker, E. V. and Yang, J. and Yan, Y. and Yang, Y. and Liu, Z.
quick_notes: maybe: compares 30m landsat to 0.5m worldview-2 imagery, based on field sampling data.  they qualitatively compare performance and show that vhr data outperforms moderate res data; but is more costly currently.  societal benefit: monitoring recovery from wildfires, informing management?  they don't quantify the benefit

title: The Role of Satellite and Decentralized Strategies in Water Resources Management
author: Gikas, Petros and Tchobanoglous, George
quick_notes: "satellite and decentralized wastewater management systems" - that sense of "satellite"

title: Integrating Drone Imagery with Existing Rangeland Monitoring Programs
author: Gillan, J. K. and Karl, J. W. and {van Leeuwen}, W. J. D.
quick_notes: does not calculate a quantified value, shows that uav imagery can do a good job of classifying vegetation  type and height (for most veg types), toward "assessment, inventory, and monitoring" for rangeland management.  but when answering "is drone monitoring worth the effort?", responds no, it will not replace most of the field methods, but can be complementary.

title: Three Most Widely Used Gnss-Based Shoreline Monitoring Methods to Support Integrated Coastal Zone Management Policies
author: Goncalves, R. M. and Awange, J. L.
quick_notes: while they use gnss data, it is not remote observation - it is manual surveying using gps coordinates.  additionally, it is more comparing methods of surveying rather than calculating the value of the esi data (such as it is).

title: Portability of Semantic and Spatial-Temporal Machine Learning Methods to Analyse Social Media for near-Real-Time Disaster Monitoring
author: Havas, Clemens and Resch, Bernd
quick_notes: very interesting, looking at tweet analysis as a way to understand natural disasters in near real time, compared to "official" products like usgs info.  however, the emphasis is more on validating an approach, rather than showing the added value that such an approach would have (not to mention, tweets aren't esi per se).

title: From Forest Dynamics to Wetland Siltation in Mountainous Landscapes: A Rs-Based Framework for Enhancing Erosion Control
author: Hernandez-Romero}, Gonzalo and {Alvarez-Martinez}, Jose Manuel and {Perez-Silos}, Ignacio and {Silio-Calzada}, Ana and Vieites, David R. and Barquin, Jose
quick_notes: satellite-based ro data to classify lulc, which enables identification of lulc dynamics and prioritization of nature-based solutions for conservation and resource management.  but they don?t compare the value achieved based on the rs method!

title: The Emerging Role of Satellite Rainfall Data in Improving the Hydro-Political Situation of Flood Monitoring in the under-Developed Regions of the World
author: Hossain, Faisal and Katiyar, Nitin and Hong, Yang and Wolf, Aaron
quick_notes: focuses on a model for watersheds, the "open book" watershed idealization, rather than the eo data that might go into the model

title: Extending the Utility of Modis Daily Snow-Cover Products through Snow-Cover Prediction of Cloud-Obscured Areas in Idaho's Big Lost River Basin (Usa)
author: Hruska, Ryan C. and Lee, Randy
quick_notes: improves utility of modis data for estimating snow cover, using a logic algorithm.  does not connect to societal value except in passing.

title: Assessing the Role of Climate and Resource Management on Groundwater Dependent Ecosystem Changes in Arid Environments with the Landsat Archive
author: Huntington, Justin and McGwire, Kenneth and Morton, Charles and Snyder, Keirith and Peterson, Sarah and Erickson, Tyler and Niswonger, Richard and Carroll, Rosemary and Smith, Guy and Allen, Richard
quick_notes: compares results of ndvi calculations between landsat 7 and landsat 8, using different atmospheric correction algorithms.  more validation/calibration type

title: Applications and Research Using Remote Sensing for Rangeland Management
author: Hunt Jr, E. R. and Everitt, J. H. and Ritchie, J. C. and Moran, M. S. and Booth, D. T. and Anderson, G. L. and Clark, P. E. and Seyfried, M. S.
quick_notes: NA

title: The Value of Site-Specific Information and the Environment: Technology Adoption and Pesticide Use under Uncertainty
author: Isik, M and Hudson, D and Coble, {\relax KH

author: I. Volke, M. and {Abarca-Del-Rio}, R. and A. Warner, T.

title: Spectral Matching Based on Discrete Particle Swarm Optimization: A New Method for Terrestrial Water Body Extraction Using Multi-Temporal Landsat 8 Images
author: Jia, Kai and Jiang, Weiguo and Li, Jing and Tang, Zhenghong

title: Where's Woolly? An Integrative Use of Remote Sensing to Improve Predictions of the Spatial Distribution of an Invasive Forest Pest the Hemlock Woolly Adelgid

author: Lehmann, Jan R. K. and Prinz, Torsten and Ziller, Silvia R. and Thiele, Jan and Heringer, Gustavo and {Meira-Neto}, Joao A. A. and Buttschardt, Tillmann K.
